passage_text: Travel between offices: You can take a mileage deduction for travel from your office or work site and your drive to a second place of business. Errands/supplies: Driving for business-related errands such as trips to the bank, office supply store or post office all qualify for a mileage deduction.

If you drive your car or other vehicle for business purposes, you can take a mileage deduction of 57.5 cents for every mile you drive for work. Here is everything you need to know in order to get the most out of your mileage write off.

If you work multiple jobs, you can deduct the mileage you travel from one job to another, but not the miles you drive from your home to your workplace or vice versa. The mileage rate for business miles was 55.5 cents per mile in 2012 and 56.5 cents per mile in 2013.

The mileage from your home to your first job or from your second job to your home is not deductible. For example, suppose your home is 15 miles from your first job and 27 miles from your second job. The two jobs are 25 miles apart. You can only claim the 25 miles you drive between your two workplaces.

Standard mileage rate. Generally, if you claim a business deduction for work-related education and you drive your car to and from school, the amount you can deduct for miles driven from January 1, 2014, through December 31, 2014, is 56 cents per mile.

Per IRS rules, you can only claim the amount of expenses that is more than 2 percent of your adjusted gross income. So if you earn $40,000 a year, you could deduct any mileage expenses of more than $800 annually.To help calculate your deduction, read the 2014 mileage rate schedule.
